data.title: ‘Out of this world’: 16yo sensation stuns darts world with ‘unbelievable’ upset
data.meta_description: ‘Out of this world’: 16yo sensation taking darts by storm with unthinkable run
data.text:
Something very, very special is unfolding in the darts world right now.

Teenager Luke Littler has stormed into the quarterfinals of the PDC Darts World Championships, defeating a legend of the sport in a stunning upset.

In a raucous atmosphere in London’s Alexandra Palace, the 16-year-old demolished five-time world champion Raymond van Barneveld four sets to one.

Stream Over 50 Sports Live & On-Demand with Kayo. New to Kayo? Start Your Free Trial Today >

Littler raced through the first three sets and kept his cool to close out the match after van Barneveld won a set to get on the board.

The world youth champion nailed nine 180s and had 14 doubles at a rate of 50 per cent, averaging a score of 105 for the match.

It was a remarkably mature performance by Littler, who was embraced by van Barneveld in touching scenes as the teenager defeated his idol.

The Sky Sports commentator said: “He’s been brushed aside. One of the best to ever play the game, he’s been walloped.

“Incredible. This is out of this world by a young man who genuinely believes he can be world champion.”

Three-time world champion John Part said on Sky Sports: “If you put aside the fact that he’s 16, that’s the sort of performance that can win the tournament.

“A great performance. That’s the sort of darts that wins titles and he’s getting awfully close to achieving that. That’s his best performance yet.”

Littler’s fairytale run has made him a cult hero in the UK and the youngster, who sports an impressive beard, was lost for words after his latest win.

“Unbelievable. I don’t know what to say,” he said after the round of 16 match.

“It’s unbelievable. I went 2-0 up, 3-0 up, then I just said to my family, ‘Three legs away, one set away and I’m over the line’. I’ve done it.”

Asked about his embrace with van Barneveld, Littler said: “He said, ‘You can go all the way. I hope you can go all the way’. I said thank you. He’s a true gentleman and I respect Raymond very well.”

The results means Littler will also pocket 50,000 pounds (AU$93,000) in prize money.

In the quarterfinals Littler will next face Brendon Nolan, who has defeated Gerwen Price and Gary Anderson.

“I do fancy myself. But let’s just focus on Brendan,” Littler said when asked if he can go all the way.

Three-time world champion Michael van Gerwen is still in the mix, but defending champion Michael Smith is out of contention after he was knocked out by Chris Dobey.
